titleInfo.title: Do You Feel Confident Enough to Seek Help
titleInfo.subTitle: The Relationship between Mental Health Confidence and Help Seeking in Military Members

name.namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems

mods:mods.abstract: Literature review supports that when looking at help-seeking behaviors, specifically, in the military population, there is a significant amount of service members who endorse mental health concerns or distress, but do not seek help for their mental health (Hom, Stanley, Schneider, & Joiner, 2017) The range of mental health concerns include depression, anxiety, adjustment disorder, posttraumatic stress, and suicidal ideations and substance abuse behaviors to name a few (Waitzkin, et al., 2018). Physiological concerns may also arise when mental health concerns are not attended to within the military which primarily have been supported to be exhibited as unsolicited weight gain, insomnia, and maladaptive coping strategies (Maclean, 2012; Heyat, Akhtar, Ansari, Khan, Alkahtani, Khan, & Lai, 2021). A sample of 102 adult participants (ages 18-59) were recruited from a Southern state Army National Guard unit. For the first research question, a linear regression model was utilized to investigate the relationship between General Self-Efficacy and Mental Health Confidence. The first research question asked: 1) Does general self-efficacy have a positive correlation with mental health confidence? The second research question utilized a path analysis primarily focused on a mediation model. The second research question investigated: 2) Does mental health confidence have a strong correlation with help-seeking intentions and help-seeking attitudes mediated by military stigma or self-reliance? Measures included were the General Self-Efficacy Scale, Mental Health Confidence Scale, Help-Seeking Intention Scale, Help-Seeking Attitude Scale, Military Stigma Scale, Self-Reliance Scale, and a series of military service-related questions and demographic items. The gathered data was analyzed utilizing linear regression and mediation path analysis. Results from the Analyses chapter support that General Self-Efficacy does have a significant and positive correlation to Mental Health Confidence; as well, Military Stigma did significantly partially mediate and Self-Reliance-Counterdependence fully mediate the relationship between Mental Health Confidence and Help-Seeking Intentions. Implications and considerations for theory, clinical practice, and future research are discussed.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Help-Seeking, Mental Health Confidence, Military, Military Stigma, Self-Efficacy, Self-Reliance
Martin Swanbrow Becker, Professor Directing Dissertation; Thomas Joiner, University Representative; Deborah Ebener, Committee Member; Lyndsay Jenkins, Committee Member.
